well, if its true.. .. will be pleased some politician agrees with his attitudes about the south! that'll put him in a quandary! a capitalist profiteer with a bigotry he shares...how can he deny him?? he might get appointed director of southern dentistry!
two months later, when i knew the doc had bad news for me? another 120mph drive. i was on a mission. but i couldn't take that left hook into the bridge abutment.

stop driving 120mph. i left east ga determined to get home before i died of cancer. lost 30lbs in two weeks, hadn't kept a meal down in days. a trip normally taking 6 hours, i did it in 3.5. it wasn't cancer. but i was dying.
*ajaymanhapra twitter handle minus the @

note the event in tn in 2003. wasn't till 2004 that nih trial unblinded study, revealed one med combo was showing 21% failure rates and high toxicity, permitted study participants to change meds. i chose to stay on it, but in 2007 i became a victim too, and had to change.

his background has also been 'sanitized' as i read many articles painting him as agreeable in 1991.. ..after actup stormed the hill with thousands of dying protestors! i did find this interesting article...

with pmtf report added to fy21 budget proposal, its clear.. ..no one on hill cares for millions of patients shamed, stigmatized, used as cash cows for 'drill mills', implant mfgrs, , integrative medicine, pharma mfgrs. i present now to you. read it!

i wrote this letter to congress a year ago, per request of another advocate meeting with her local reps, in hopes  would include it in a senate committee oversight hearing of dea overreach. never happened. problem remains....
a few tidbits about that advocacy, my lost career, and a program that literally saved my life.

let me pound on her hands for a few decades, maybe she'll get dupuytrens, some severe osteoarthritis. then let her get that blister pack open without cracking half the pill and slinging it into the couch. they sent my bp meds in blister pack. i will be requesting they stop.

i'm used to shaming by right-wing nutjobs that think hiv is god's curse on gays, promiscuous, drug users. to get that slander from a medical professional claiming a progressive stand, who stands behind an industry corrupted by capitalist profiteering pissmafia? unforgivable.

i witnessed that shaming. if you disagree with him, and he sees a political persuasion different than his, he will assault you relentlessly. if you disagree, and there's no indication of political position, he'll assign one, that frees him mentally to assault you.

that event stopped personal attacks on me. i even noticed an attempt by ms to control his bigotry, although it still fails, he still presents himself as an intellectual supremacist. he exposed dirty bigotry that day, in attempt to shame me into silence the worst possible way.

events after the ama pronouncements to cdc took a decidedly nasty turn, and on the exact day the international aids conference was hosting their seminars on hiv stigma... ms exposed his stigma, crossed a line that cannot be fixed. search me under hashtag hivstigma for details.

i watched him belittle and shame people that disagreed. overlooked it last year. after february it was impossible to ignore. borderlines sealed that deal. i could still possibly mend fences, ms does have positions i agree with. however...

for those that attacked us due to war with ms, i have to add one further event. my first medical advocacy is hiv survival, hell i lost my career standing my ground for 17 yrs of research trial appts! we face serious stigma from medical professionals, bad as cpp face now!

our divide took place, not with personalities and attitude, but with protest, slander, attack. we had to split, and block to stop the distracting attacks on our discussions. those attacks ended only recently, as ama became our justification. so now? a whitewashing of disputes.

this invoked all-out war. our group was assaulted so bad, by drug users, by ms sycophants. ms declares all of us mentally disordered, commits to research to prove it. you can follow that with hashtags 25psychocpp, borderlines. by then, i saw lauren and shasta in a new light!

in feb, parallel to attacks on kline, a new pain patients rights bill was introduced in wa state, included 'informed consent' waivers protecting doctors. ms declares he would intercede, force legislators to add his mandatory monthly forced udt to bill. we protested against him.

...a year later, i learned more. more solid evidence turned 'conspiracy' into policy. vanila singh turned on us. kline was attacked by schatman, then ncmb, and nc34 abandoned. more internal documents exposed. then ms went one step further...

honesty time. when i got here 2/2019, issues were simple - get meds back publicize our plight, that'll solve problem. i read violation of a nation, thought it conspiracy, considered lauren, shasta outside mainstream. considered ms a brash advocate with one bad policy. but...

to 's credit (for which i give very reluctantly due to his overwhelming bigotry), he is adamant about bupe being totally ineffective as pain med. his support for full-agonist opioid is unwavering - except for higher doses. parable of blind pig and acorn comes to mind.
the above tweet covers the disabled. this tweet covers his use of a nation filled with drug abusers fuelled by the state.

once upon a time, before kolodny, government made policies leading disabled into a short life and torturous death, and locking drug users into a life of servitude to the state. kolodny's bupe does that medicinally. hitler's method was more direct... https://www.ushmm.org/collections/bibliography/people-with-disabilities

i postulate someday, bupe will be named 'ultimate gateway drug'. leaves drug users physically dependent, in a stupor, lacking that euphoria they crave. leaves pain patients in the same stupor, without treating severe pain. both groups will be seeking. is that their goal?

treating pain in a trauma crisis us a risky balance, enough powerful opioid must be administered to overcome bupe. but at some point all bupe leaves receptors, causing tolerance to plummet, and overdose risk to skyrocket. how many lives will bupe torture? how many saved?

with the new synthetics flooding black market, drug users can bupe on weekdays, get really high on weekends, and still pass the monday morning piss test. while pain patients in a trauma crisis are placed in precarious position of either excruciating pain untreated, or overdose.

bupe fails to address pain, but imparts a lasting 'pacifying' effect leaving users in a stupor. tight binding to receptors prevents most opioids from attaching. this makes pain care hazardous in a trauma emergency. while drug users find powerful illicits do overcome bupe.

relieved to say, after ending three years of hormone ablation, with fears that i might someday be wearing my wife's bras, puberty has come to the 'fatbiker. with hair on my chest, and a deepening voice, i reclaim my maleness. still no sam elliot. sorry for the confusion.
i'd like to pick that back up tomorrow. my wife and her doggie abandoned me, my doggies whining to go join them. its bedtime. till then...

and none of those three have made any public response pro or con regarding the ama pronouncements. it's as if they have invalidated it, and working as hard to silence it as they want to do to us. that's a problem.

i would like to discuss some of it in a non-contentious way. issues are more than disputes within, we've been betrayed by one high-ranking 'advocate', we have another academic that shames those opposing policies, an org claiming to back us while industry backs them pushing pmtf.
i was scared i'd lose 70% of my followers just for saying it! guess we're not all raging psychotics angling for a fight, and i proved it. now, if i had called someone that...

so let's not belittle the major policy differences in our groups. to get us together, they must be discussed. maybe there is a compromise, i don't know. but we won't get there by lining up and shaking hands and singing kumbaya.

the recent proclamations by ama vindicated our position, should be empowering pushback against congress and cdc. we did see an end to the attacks on us in regards to mandatory monthly udt. instead we get this article, implying it's all personalities and bad attitude.

some want to fight to change system, as we feel it was built on lies. our medications were effective, not inherently dangerous, our lives were functional in spite of our ailments. we are not a public health hazard, or psychologically unstable. limiting our care saved no lives.

and all of the above, we're still saddled with excessive office visits, rigorous expensive unreliable monitoring, onerous pm contracts. not seeing how that will work and not leave way too many falling out of care, undertreated, or in crisis due to invasive procedure failures.

some want to work within a system already hamstrung by cdc guidelines, with a brick wall of pmtf looming over us. 'getting our meds back' in that context means forging an exemption for us that avoids the step ladder of goat yoga, psychoanalysis, esi, nsaids, and bupe.
we need more discussion of the 'petty' issues that split our community, as they are not so petty. and they do impact lives.

what infuriates me? the animosity peter witnessed recently during our 'split' was focused on issues! yet, no mention of those issues beyond 'petty'. why? ama. we were vindicated. we disagree with ms, darnell, us pain, pmtf and its inside belbuca lobbyist. write that article!

i think a fast-tracked vaccine with barely a beginning of real phase iii trial, should complete its trial with millions of healthy people for a year or two before its thrust upon elderly and immunocompromised. we're not your lab rats. do your part. i'll wait....

integrated care and broader reimbursements will be a bonanza for psychologists and goat-yoga practitioners. it will not help pain care patients who have permanent physical disorders with daily severe pain. ama agrees. you should too.
yes. guess he thought we'd take his word for it. or, his reading comprehension sucked.
followed. lauren and shasta are an awesome pair. your access could be critical! thank you.
aja posted a research article claiming nsaids worked as well as opioids. i called him on it. the research pitted nsaids against buprenorphine. wish i'd kept it now. ibuprofen beats bupe. bupesucks.
i won't be taking any vaccines produced under a rushed timeline. i'll let a few million of you finish their phase iii trials for them first. i'll wait and watch.

four years of an inflamed gall bladder full of rocks, with severe gerd, fetal-position cramping, pawned off as hiv side effects. i blasted the enterologist that said he wanted to check for....stomach herpes. the crap i've dealt with. hivstigma.

then, she resigns from hhs, and becomes a board member. pmtf is released pushing bupe as preferred med. then she shows at ihpc, next? pmtf is added to fy21 budget by . sorry, but methinks she did say it.

vanila singh played us. while she was an officer of hhs, working on pmtf report, this was taking place at bdsi, pushing their patented buprenorphine formulation for pain. belbuca gets preferred status. other cheaper pain meds get prior auth.

i posted above series of tweets in april. ama response to cdc in june is identical. it's clear, opinion that frequent forced udt endangers pain care, therefore lives, is shared by more than borderlines. not petty, unless advocates want to pick-n-choose who gets left behind.

yeah, making people illegal does so much for us. any public health threat, just round 'em up so no one else has to deal with them. me, others like me, said for years, dammit if they insist we be quarantined, we'll take island of maui. bigots always insist on round-ups. meh.
did i fail to tag  enough? my responses to your article are for you. and   even . before you spread this story of stigma and lies, dig deeper.

oud is a misnomer, a kolodny euphemism for 'addict in denial'. dependence is not addiction. and a patient with permanent disabling conditions cannot be simply 'detoxed'. but that's what's happening in us, coming to uk if someone doesn't call them on it.

try "veteran discharged from pain care killed themselves after va repeatedly refused to treat debilitating pain" as a title. i'm sure he was dependent on pain meds as that comes with permanent intractable pain. per kolodny, he was labeled as 'opioid use disorder'. meh.

a little more investigation is in order. 22 veteran suicides a day are not opioid addicts, they are patients refused treatment for debilitating pain, as va was the first entity in us dictated to cut off all veterans from pain care. this is a fail.

amazing this story glosses over his pain and degenerating back condition. we know in 2014, he wasn't detoxed, he was force-tapered with no regard for physical or mental health. of course he still had pain and ptsd. and he knew more psych and goat yoga wasn't gonna fix it.

this series of tweets from an interesting thread i posted last week references the differences between addiction and a simple drug dependence. i'll note most patients don't get as strong dependence as addicts, because we don't take as much to get high.

wasn't till after brachytherapy for prostate cn forced me on them 2 months, i developed dependence. when pain dropped, i tapered, stopped, went back to work. no cravings. some sleepless nights, then i was normal. addicts also develop dependence. but dependence is not addiction.

what's funny is i once thought like you, i didn't get opioids until after losing a gall bladder and severe gerd combined with nsaids hobbled me. had 4x for next 10 years. scared to take them more than 2 days in a row. i feared that junkie-monkey on my back!
i reference what i say.

yes, you might lose less than 1% of pain care patients, as our demographic weighs heavily towards elderly and disabled, long ago beyond the youthful rec users seeking a high. how many of us should suffer and die, to save them? oh. but it won't. they're dying of illegal drugs.

thank you . a very balanced, on target article! it's hard to name the issues you didn't hit! maybe you should be editing for ! god knows  seriously needs it! https://filtermag-org.cdn.ampproject.org/c/s/filtermag.org/why-the-opioid-pharma-hatred-is-overblown-and-harmful/amp/

my doc will probably sneer when she sees i lost only 5lbs from last visit. that'll trigger me. i gained 10 more, while on a diet that drives my wife into hypoglycemia! then i lost 15lbs. and wife adds meals to her diet to make up the difference.

i'm not on pain meds, i got booted last year cause i rejected epidural spinal injections. last two esi 2016 didn't help...unless you consider flaring dormant undetected cancer into aggressive stageiii prostate cn 'help'. hiv survivors can't take steroids. yet they push them.

medicare covers my old med. i also have another combo in mind that uses similar meds, replaces tdf with taf, reduces efavirenz from 600mg to 200mg. unfortunately i had to suffer, present outcome-based results, to overcome her distaste for dr. google. meh.

this is my hiv meds, atripla falling out of favor due to tdf fears, efavirenz psychoactivity...and gilead patent expirations. got switched last year cause ins. dropped it. switched back in feb. cause i had extra, couldn't get bp down. was hoping doc would compromise in may.

i'm only now cutting weight i gained last time i took it for 6 months. old drug wasn't bad either..but its disfavored, patents expiring. i switched back during lockdown. cd4 skyrocketed! bp went down. rode my trike 350 miles. y'all know i'm loaded for bear when i see her again.

i'm doing better, but june took me down. doc made me switch back on a med, didn't buy my complaints about bp and weight. and she wanted me to lose weight. get me back on my old med, it'll lose itself damn weight shot up 10lbs in two weeks! finally dropping....

oh i wish he had the clout to flood local networks with ads. he's running against a clown show, his opponents are like three stooges, but no one knows which one is mo.  is the only sane choice for me.

i think it's a distraction to keep us arguing while orgs like you backdoor the hhs pmtf into legislation. after that's done, it's all psychological, goat yoga, behavioral therapy. and if you're good, you get some bupe, develop dependence, expand bdsi, indivor stock portfolios.

one of these orgs tagged fail to seek facts (thats you, brian). the other reported truth via local affiliates. maybe today show can sort this out? stop a crisis, by telling truth about the other crisis.

someone tell brian mann and his npr handlers, quick! did you see nbc piece ran on local affiliates? don't rage on the cover pic...it surprisingly makes our point. there's plenty of baggies, spoons, and needles in the report. and it references ama too.

but pounding him and his tax assessor in state courts, telling him on front page to kiss my ass, sign judgement levied by state, threatening to have him cuffed and jailed, destroying his political career? priceless. and a bit more courage. hivstigma sucks. so does painstigma.

i wouldn't call this courage, but thank you for the confidence. fighting managers to stay employed, a bit of courage. confronting a mayor, with county commission, armed codes officers, leo, attorneys, and 40 protestors trying to run us out of our new home, a bit more, and $$$

isn't it ironic, agenda-driven orgs with self-interest are pushing pain care and addiction tx into the same bottleneck? bupe is a poor analgesic, but develops dependence fast and as hard as the strongest opioids. once they're done, we'll all be locked in, cash cows for pharma.

the research assistants sometimes remarked about my travels, and that trip to brazil was a biggie. manaus is a city buried in the middle of amazon, you get there by plane or boat. no roads in or out, just rainforest. but it's full of japanese factories. go figure.

we're cool, just sharing my experience as high-risk patient using that exact combo. my report is not anecdotal, everything i've done medically has been quantified by research trials for 20 years. lifer lab rat. hell for all we know trump did this to boost his gilead stock.

it was this one, i ss it below. the success and failures of all these treatments got buried in politics. i suspect every politician has taken a stand on hcq, ivermectin, remdesivir, vaccines, based on their stock portfolios and campaign funds. that's what they do. screw us.
i suggest polite educational responses. he's outside our bubble, buys what media feeds.

the 'opioid' crisis (illegal drug overdoses) began long before so-called 'overprescribing', is exploding now, long after prescribing has been decimated. a thread, with sub-thread, all referenced. i hope it's an eye-opener, as millions are suffering.

yes, it might, but those interactions overblown as scare tactic. haven't we learned how that works already? as hiv survivor, preps for a week in brazil? hcq, z-pack, yellow fever shot. nih research trial docs approved, monitored. not many of us worked like i did. jus saying'.

i swear, design engineers are so dense sometimes. they make purty drawings on cad workstations, so proud of their solidworks skill. can't tell you times i had to drag them out of their offices onto a hot noisy dirty production floor, educate them on how stupid their idea was.

i got better idea. assemble group of design engineers. bust 'em up from hips down. send them home on furlough with one of these babies for three months. take all cost out of their paychecks. wheel them back to workstations. functional, economical will be on their minds.
brown recluses were trying to make a home in my shed. i moved them to valhalla.
yes. he was bad boy. now he's hardened twitmo convict.

disabled people in pain are not a community health threat! that's stigmatizing. youth with ankle sprains are not getting ex. neither are we.  has fallen. even nbc is reporting drops in prescriptions, and an illegal fentanyl / cocaine / meth crisis.
well, if you misbehave, and get yourself thrown in twitmo, have a chat with don jr before he gets sprung, he can give you his copy.

found video. what's notable in my opinion? ama. no media would report drop in rx, or blame it on illegal drugs, if they had not came forward. https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/health/overdose-surge-mirrors-coronavirus-pandemic/2414843/

i am shocked shocked i tell you! nbc news on local reporting dramatic rise in od. graphics had balance of rx and illegal drugs. meh. but the report? all illegal drugs, they even noted rx dropping for years, od rising due to illicit fentanyl, meth, cocaine. media told truth!

trivializing and worse, heckling impact of medical record information, and medical disorders, on employment, custody, and future medical care, is harming patients as much as denial of care. don't ignore it. and stop doing it.
if pain can't be controlled by a sloppy dog smooching... ...the whiskey and stick protocol is a valid option. 9 out of 10 pain refugees agree - it beats goat yoga, voodoo hexes, and harp music!
i would go further, his chart is not what he says it is, his data is fabricated, and there's already plenty of proof in this thread alone. he's a zealot lying for an agenda.

with pain care, this paradigm has been turned on its head. we're publicly labeled a threat, and system isolates us, denies us care, risk mitigation applied to patient, not system. that's straight up violation of civil rights, denial of care, inequality. destruction of lives.

i remember politicians and public screaming for tests, isolation, monitoring, even quarantines. laws established limits, assured protections, forced universal precautions and risk mitigation. instead of isolating me from system, discriminatory treatment, system had to adapt.

because we're declared a threat, we must be stringently monitored, forced thru marginal and useless therapies, with limited access to bupe only after failure. fall thru cracks? a sacrifice for public good. i know what being labeled a threat means. laws were made to protect us.

now that vanila singh has joined with others directly blaming 50 million patients for escalating an illegal drug crisis, it should be clear. community was never divided. but our trust was abused. industry advocates are profiteering from an illusion we're a public health threat.

article focuses too much on angry patients in desperation. acts as if any improvement in access is a good thing we should support. no recognition how many of us are desperate exactly because we're already pushed into these modalities. just more 'get along they know best'.

and, don't even get me started on one professional advocate, with many agreeable positions, but promoting use of abusive, discriminatory procedure...who spares no stigma, slander, or marginalization silencing dissent. peter, your article is misleading, incomplete, and damaging.

article failed to address real policy differences. glossed over them as 'disagreements'. nps. pmtf. udt. public health vs individualized care. glossed over real physical distress like it was a personality problem. failed to note major betrayals (singh. us pain.)

insurers already onboard with giving belbuca preferred status, putting full-agonist as restricted. before vanila singh had departed, before ink was laid to final pmtf draft, bdsi secured belbuca as preferred. then showed their thanks to singh as she went out the door of hhs.

and how far back has illicit fentanyl been labeled as rx od? it didn't start in 2012, or 1999, it began as early...as 1976. this article from 1981, "a new and seriously different era of opiate addiction and treatment". from my 'prescription' thread.

it's definitely after 2017 per references. what's unspoken but inferred simply by omission? because coroners don't routinely test for illicit fentanyl analogues, their standard tests only detect metabolite breakdown products presenting as synthetic opioid.

if i'm ever pushed into acupuncture as therapy... ...i'll be sure waiting room knows all about my three-letter, make some comments about reused needles, as i go back. they won't be there when i get out.
spent entire concert backstage. failed my mid-term next morning, blew my 100% average in that course. worth it.

why i was there? i pleas fifth. statute of limitations. i did meet lead singer for flock of seagulls. he ran into dressing room in his underwear, dumped a baggie into a paper the size of new york times, rolled it, ran out door for tour bus with a huge doobie behind his ear.

i've seen the fixx perform once. it was first time they performed many songs from 'shuttered room', onstage, grand ole opry. i missed all of it. missed flock of seagulls too. backstage guest, we got acoustic and grand piano close up and personal. https://www.setlist.fm/stats/songs/the-fixx-6bd6b65a.html?song=saved+by+zero

some rock stars kept their health, but it takes radical changes to go from backstage drug party youth, to something akin to jack lalanne. i've seen mick jagger twice. and he still runs that stage today, long after petty and prince and others died for it.

long after these music icons have left drug use behind, they can't give up the euphoria of performing for thousands of fans. that is an addiction! long after we'd end a career so physically abusive, they will keep busting themselves up to get another night on the stage.

i read that. there is conflation between addiction and dependence. it also glosses over undertreatment. and 'all docs want to treat the rock star'? no, no doc wants to be the one who kills the rock star. leaving them relief-seeking elsewhere, instead of giving up the stage.
when you produce a story for npr, does anyone fact-check your work? they should. using a drug overdose chart, pushing it as prescription, is fraud in journalism.

this is a graphic of illegal drug overdose. not prescriptions. stop lying to make a point. there's little prescribing in tn. pain care is decimated. tn law is the strictest in nation. yet, overdoses rise. as illustrated by your graph! https://reason.com/2019/10/22/as-tennessee-forces-opioid-prescription-cutbacks-more-people-are-dying-of-overdoses/?amp&__twitter_impression=true
i lost a week of work due to torn calf muscles. i lied to my doctor of course. and to my employer. but wife knew the truth. so did our roommates.
omg i have a dozen comments for this tweet and dammit i can't make any of them!!!

that horn was collector's item, all performers had to have it. i worked my butt off in 8th grade to buy it for $400. valued two years later at $2800. every time i went to a contest or composers festival, all the other sax players drooled over it.

wanna-be rockstar didn't pay the bills. dropped out of music performance & theory coursework. engineering technology was a more assured income. and i still ended up travelling from town to town ,living in hotel rooms. alto sax was my baby. selmer markvi, low serial classic.

doctors need flexibility to expedite a diagnosis, begin effective treatment plan. if you need counseling, you get it. if you metabolize fast, need partial agonist with long binding affinity, you get it. if you have crumbling hips, or a rare disease, 'step' therapy is torture.

that totally makes sense, you require an opioid with a longer binding affinity. and, after many many hours of goat yoga, some vr distraction, vigorous counseling sessions.. ..some foot-stomping to make you forget hip pain... ..and mega-doses of .. ..then they'll rx.

many like myself were blocked for one reason. pissmafia. ms wants policy of excessive testing funded by taxpayers. claims its science-based. we want policy as recommended by american medical association. outcome-based science.

it would be first of 6 years dea warned congress of three distributors with abnormally large allotments of opioid, pleaded for them to disapprove it. congress gave them the finger. too much pharma money in their pockets. 'fast n furious' on oxycodone.

won't be improved by pmtf, pushed forward by your lobbying efforts. making clinical practice guidelines for 'special populations' based on sex, age, etc. is discriminatory. most people needing long-term pain care are disabled. we need protection. not goat yoga. ada30

we prepared for disability and disaster. rural, low joint mortgage, never put wife's name on my debts. my debtors can't seize her home. no worries of covid from neighbors 1200 ft away. and we survived 22 months with her ssdi (barely). if only someone would mow it for free.
i saw nothing. that's my story. sticking to it.
the goat-yoga practitioners, biopsychosocial brigades, and vanila singh make out like bandits, u.s pain gets kickbacks. and patients suffer.
oh, they're doing something. for healthy people. not us

i told nicole hemmingway to take me off mailing list. this is corrupted industry advocacy, not representing interests of disabled, damaged, diseased in pain. the pmtf is a gift package for bdsi, pacira, american psychological association, integrative health policy coalition.
damn. i looked at my phone just a few seconds ago. 91 degrees. you must live next door or something.

let's add some more information addressing pmtf, alternate modalities, belbuca, and featuring the ultimate insider unregistered lobbyist vanila singh. in response to integrative health care coalition. you heard from them. hear from us, the patients.

let's also look at other analgesia options that will be applied before its decided more pain care needed. with a host of complications. may be ok for healthy people. that's not us. but i guess our organs are expendable for the public good?

let's visit an accurate representation of how ongoing drug crisis evolved. it started before oxycontin. continues while prescriptions plummet, covid patients tortured due to lack of sedatives for ventilators. making disabled suffer didn't help one bit.

all due to propaganda. blaming 50 million citizens in pain - many of them disabled - for overwhelmingly illegal drug overdose crisis, is inequality. discrimination. on ada30 we don't need pmtf. we need  recommendations to be applied and enforced.

note package insert warnings. "belbuca exposes patients and other users to risks of opioid addiction, abuse, misuse, which can lead to overdose and death.." drug users refer to bupe as 'prison heroin' as it gives them a calm, and keeps tolerance high.

"as soon as the patients body eliminates all of the buprenorphine, the new opioid will be able to occupy all available mors. this abrupt transition could greatly increase frequency of side effects and risk of opioid-induced respiratory depression." disabled in pain will suffer.

if you live in flatlands with moderate hills, hub drive is ok, but i live in hillbilly land, lots of hollers, lot of climbing. i imagine 8-speed with mid-drive would be good for almost everything, but i'd run smallest front sprocket available if you run hillbilly like i do. 4/5

my favorite stones song, with keith richards singing lead...
he was a good friend, it was more than flattering that he trusted me to go with his wife to see stones in birmingham years later.

a year later, good friend introduces me to his fiancee. we looked at each other...she spoke first..."new orleans?" yes. 'stones?'. hell yes. my friend was bit puzzled, we had to fill him in, she was in convoy, had the rooms with the french quarter balcony, yes we met before!
nothing like a takeover of french quarter and bourbon street for three days with 30 friends and 80,000 rockers!

all same county as us, all have cb, they call us, we agree to meet at next rest stop! we knew some, our riding buddies knew some, now our subdued ride of 4, was a convoy of 30! from that point on it was all-out party! we hit bourbon street as a gang!

'going to the stones!' that night, lunch break, note on our ride's car, two others wanting to split gas, hotel if we needed a ride, leaving thurs morn. hell yes! barely knew either. things a bit subdued first few hours. but outside birmingham, i-10 headed west, caravan passes..

he hits boss up on wednesday night, tells him he's not working thurs, fri, says he's going to stones, waves his ticket. boss tells him wait... ..then boss asks me, 'hey, it's your business, you got days off, but, if it's ok, can you tell me why?' i smiled, pulled ticket out.

..i give ticket to friend i work with, his birthday. tell him wait to ask off, let me first (boss liked me better). asked boss for thursday and friday off, tell him its personal, he gives it to me. mind you, friend didn't have a car either. we vowed we'd hitchhike if we had to.

i knew about the concert, big deal on mtv they had a learjet concert promo going. well, next morn, everyone backs out, i say gimme the tickets i'm going. don't know who with, or how, or where to stay, have no car, gotta work, but dammit i was going. that monday...

it was! how it happened, story in itself! me and another friend out with two girls we knew from vol state, one says something about going to a concert that next week, says she has two tickets. i ask where, she says superdome. friend asks who...i say dumbass, not who, stones!

today's ride became unexpected adventure, three hours, battery in low teens, boombot died, had to use gps to find my truck and prayed it was close! it was a blast. last time i rode a bicycle in my hometown was 1975. you can go home again. but don't expect your landmarks.

doctors cannot note patients as non-compliant when conditions can be treated with multiple modalities (i.e. oral meds, shots, implants, surgery), and patient refuses one or more of the options presented. patient has rights to refuse and choose risks, without retribution.

udt must be linked to medical necessity, and cannot be shared with anyone or any agency. detection of legal substances (nicotine, caffeine, cbd, thc, alcohol) cannot be used as grounds for non-compliance without other indicators of abuse.

nothing like a takeover of french quarter and bourbon street for three days with 30 friends and 80,000 rockers!

all same county as us, all have cb, they call us, we agree to meet at next rest stop! we knew some, our riding buddies knew some, now our subdued ride of 4, was a convoy of 30! from that point on it was all-out party! we hit bourbon street as a gang!

'going to the stones!' that night, lunch break, note on our ride's car, two others wanting to split gas, hotel if we needed a ride, leaving thurs morn. hell yes! barely knew either. things a bit subdued first few hours. but outside birmingham, i-10 headed west, caravan passes..

he hits boss up on wednesday night, tells him he's not working thurs, fri, says he's going to stones, waves his ticket. boss tells him wait... ..then boss asks me, 'hey, it's your business, you got days off, but, if it's ok, can you tell me why?' i smiled, pulled ticket out.

..i give ticket to friend i work with, his birthday. tell him wait to ask off, let me first (boss liked me better). asked boss for thursday and friday off, tell him its personal, he gives it to me. mind you, friend didn't have a car either. we vowed we'd hitchhike if we had to.

today's ride became unexpected adventure, three hours, battery in low teens, boombot died, had to use gps to find my truck and prayed it was close! it was a blast. last time i rode a bicycle in my hometown was 1975. you can go home again. but don't expect your landmarks.

few weeks ago, aja was pushing a study showing nsaids effective as opioids in pain tx. digging in...comparison was bupe vs. tylenol. bupe has a place, mild-moderate pain where long-term nsaids are not an option...or patient fears addiction, or has family members to protect.

bupe is not a full-agonist opioid, does not have the cardio and anti-inflammatory benefits, imparts a new risk, and works...for only mild-moderate pain. we are confirming the benefits of full-agonist opioids. and denying assertions that bupe is comparable! it is not.

is it possible, impetus for restricting all rx opioid, comes from dramatic rises in prescription abuse of bupe and methadone? so, rx more bupe, get rid of other opioid, to make addiction tx less risky for providers? wow, we've really been snookered!

but that study did yield this jewel.. "methadone is the opioid associated with the highest rate of accidental overdose death, contributing to one of three overdose deaths in 2009." does this mean most rx opioid death is methadone abuse? not pain patients?

i'm not buying into bupe as safe option for pain care! if emergency procedure needed, providers won't take risks of dosing uncertainty (how much more at first, how much to reduce later after bupe wears off). once bupe becomes common, full-agonist opioids will be banned.

naltrexone has no analgesia, but its effect on glial cells imparts an anti-inflammatory effect. its a bit paradoxical, the full-binding antagonist works similiar to full agonist in that regard. bupe, being partial, has no anti-inflammatory effect.

a third question would be 'was 100 billion opioids enough?' 'first wave / overprescribing' theory a pile of fabricated crap. few of us remember docs handing it out like candy. we had to go thru the hoops then. now, 'lucky' ones are treated like parolees. rest are denied.
